data.name: In the Mandelbrot Set?
data.description:
Introduction

The Mandelbrot set is the set of complex numbers c for which the function: fc(z) = z2 + c doesn't diverge (i.e. gets increasingly large in magnitide) when iterated from z = 0. Thus for a complex numbers to be in the Mandelbrot set it must remain bounded (more precisely |z| < 2) when iterated infinitely many times through the function. But how then are we to decide whether a given complex number is in the set or not? We don't have forever, and even then 'infinitely many times' is just one too many. So instead of trying to do the impossible we set ourselves a limit for how many times a given complex number must be iterated (whilst remaining below 2 in magnitude) to be accepted into the Mandelbrot set. But why are we interested in this in the first place you might ask? Well, here is a visualisation of an area in the Mandelbrot set in the complex plane. The colors indicate the amount of iterations before the complex number at that point began diverging. Pretty cool right? ![Mandelbrot set](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/37/Mandel_zoom_14_satellite_julia_island.jpg)

Task

Your task is write a function that takes in a complex number c (as a string) and a positive integer n and returns a boolean value to indicate whether c is in the Mandelbrot set or not when fc(z) is iterated n times. Expect n to be as big as 104. The input string will always be valid and formatted like this: ```python 'x + yi' ``` Examples of input strings: ```python '0.1 + 0.1i' '0.335339261 - 0.564117944i' '-1.22030 - 0.12806572658i' ``` Good luck and have fun!
